title: Speed of human thought lags far behind internet connection: What does a new study say? - The Indian Express
summary:
Speed of Human Thought Lags Behind Internet Connection, Study Reveals

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Indian Express

A recent study indicates that the human brain processes thought at a significantly slower rate than the speed of information flow over the internet, highlighting the limitations of human cognition.

  • The human brain processes thought at approximately 10 bits per second, while typical Wi-Fi connections handle 50 bits per second.
  • The study titled 'The unbearable slowness of being: Why do we live at 10 bits/s?' published in the journal Neuron.
  • Neuroscientist Markus Meister argues that the study suggests the human brain is much slower than commonly believed.
  • Humans can process sensory information much faster — at a rate of 100,000,000 times that of cognition.
  • The researchers suggest that this slow pace of thought is linked to evolution and environmental needs.
  • Some experts question the study's methodology and suggest it may underestimate the human nervous system's information flow.
“It is a bit of a counterweight to the endless hyperbole about how incredibly complex and powerful the human brain is… If you actually try to put numbers to it, we are incredibly slow.” - Markus Meister

This study sheds light on the inherent limitations of human cognition and raises significant questions about the nature of human thought compared to technological processing speeds.
newTitle: Speed of Human Thought Lags Behind Internet Connection, Study Reveals

title: How space junk endangers Earth's orbit: All you need to know about 'Kessler Syndrome' - The Times of India
summary:
How Space Junk Endangers Earth's Orbit: Understanding Kessler Syndrome

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: CNN

Space debris is increasingly problematic as Earth's orbit becomes congested, potentially leading to Kessler Syndrome, a catastrophic cascade of collisions in space.

  • Kessler Syndrome refers to the chain reaction of collisions in space that creates more debris.
  • Since the 1950s, over 50,000 tons of material have been launched into orbit, with approximately 13,000 tons remaining.
  • Active satellite constellations like SpaceX's Starlink are exacerbating the situation.
  • High-speed orbital debris poses a significant threat, causing the ISS to perform avoidance maneuvers frequently.
  • Efforts to mitigate space debris include cleanup technologies and international regulations.
"Proactive measures are essential to prevent irreversible damage to our orbital environment." - Dr. Nilton Renno, University of Michigan

Experts stress the importance of addressing space debris before it leads to catastrophic consequences in Earth's orbit.
newTitle: How Space Junk Endangers Earth's Orbit: Understanding Kessler Syndrome

title: NASA Warns Of Big Bus-Sized Asteroid Set For Close Encounter With Earth Tomorrow: Check Speed, Time And Distan - Times Now
summary:
NASA Warns Of Big Bus-Sized Asteroid Set For Close Encounter With Earth Tomorrow

Date: December 29, 2024

Source: Times Now News

NASA has issued an alert about a bus-sized asteroid, 2024 YA5, making a close approach to Earth, traveling at 58,948 km/h.

  • The asteroid is 31 feet wide and will pass at a distance of 351,000 kilometers from Earth.
  • This distance is closer than the Moon which is about 384,400 kilometers away.
  • 2024 YA5 poses no threat as it is classified well below the criteria for potentially hazardous asteroids (PHAs).
  • NASA emphasizes the importance of monitoring such asteroids for planetary defense and scientific research.
“Understanding their composition, behaviour, and trajectories enhances our knowledge of the solar system's history.”

This event highlights the significance of asteroid tracking and the continuous need for monitoring space objects to ensure Earth’s safety.
newTitle: NASA Warns Of Bus-Sized Asteroid Approaching Earth

title: NASA confirms solar probe has made record-breaking close approach to the Sun - Euronews
summary:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Close Approach to the Sun

Date: Latest Update

Source: NASA

The Parker Solar Probe has successfully made the closest approach to the Sun, setting a record by coming within six million kilometers of the Sun's surface.

  • The probe passed through the Sun's outer atmosphere, known as the corona.
  • It achieved speeds of 690,000 kph during its close approach.
  • The heat shield of the Parker can withstand temperatures reaching up to 1,370 degrees Celsius.
  • This mission aims to provide insights into the reasons behind the Sun's corona being significantly hotter than its surface.
  • Parker Solar Probe was launched in 2018 and is expected to continue orbiting the Sun until at least September.
“Parker Solar Probe was developed as part of NASA’s Living With a Star program to explore aspects of the Sun-Earth system that directly affect life and society,” said NASA in a statement.

This successful mission is a significant step in understanding solar phenomena and their impact on Earth.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Close Approach to the Sun

title: China's new radio telescopes put into use for deep space exploration - CGTN
summary:
China's New Radio Telescopes Enhance Deep Space Exploration

Published on: Friday, Location: China

Two radio telescopes with 40-meter-diameter antennas have been launched to aid in deep space exploration and decoding cosmic mysteries, located in northeast and southwest China.

  • The telescopes were built by the Shanghai Astronomical Observatory in Jilin Province and Xizang Autonomous Region.
  • China's Very-Long-Baseline Interferometry network now includes a control center in Shanghai and six stations, enhancing observational capabilities.
  • The telescopes allow for high-precision positioning and combining signals for a larger effective aperture in cosmic observation.
  • Observable sky area is expanded by 25%, with angular resolution improved by 18% in the X-band.
  • Previous missions supported include lunar exploration from Chang'e-1 to Chang'e-6 and the Mars mission Tianwen-1.
  • The telescopes will bolster future lunar and deep space missions.
“The two new telescopes will play an important role in future lunar exploration, as well as deep space missions...” – Ye Shuhua, Academician of CAS

In conclusion, these advancements mark a significant step in China's capability for exploring the cosmos, supporting various scientific endeavors and enhancing international collaborations in astrophysical research.
newTitle: China's New Radio Telescopes Enhance Deep Space Exploration

title: Scientists Just Proved Your Brain Operates at the Speed of a Snail—and It’s Shockingly Low - The Daily Galaxy --Great Discoveries Channel
summary:
Scientists Just Proved Your Brain Operates at the Speed of a Snail—and It’s Shockingly Low

Publication Date: [Insert Date] Source: [Insert Source]

Recent research from Caltech reveals that the human brain processes conscious thought at just 10 bits per second, a speed dramatically slower than the billion bits per second our senses can collect, prompting important questions about cognitive capabilities.

The 10-Bit Bottleneck:

  • Despite having 85 billion neurons, only 10 bits per second are processed consciously.
  • This processing speed is significantly slower than modern technologies like Wi-Fi.
“Every moment, we are extracting just 10 bits from the trillion that our senses are taking in,” said Markus Meister, highlighting the stark difference between brain capacity and processing speed.

Evolutionary Implications: The research suggests that this limitation evolved as early nervous systems focused on basic survival tasks.

  • Single-task focusing exemplifies the brain's slow yet precise processing.
“Our ancestors evolved in a world slow enough to make survival possible,” notes Zheng and Meister.

Impact on Future Technologies: The findings challenge expectations for brain-machine interfaces that aim to enhance communication speeds.

  • Neural links would still be restricted by the brain's processing limit.

Future Research Directions: The study calls for more exploration into how the brain prioritizes sensory information.

  • Understanding this selection is crucial to unlocking human cognition's architecture.

Redefining Intelligence: This study encourages defining intelligence not by speed but through an efficient and deliberate approach to processing information.

The findings reaffirm the complexity of human thought, revealing the balancing act between efficiency and precision in cognitive functions.
newTitle: Scientists Prove Human Brain Processes Thoughts at a Surprisingly Low Speed

NASA’s Parker Solar Probe survives close brush with Sun’s scorching surface - The Tribune India
summary:
NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Survives Close Brush with Sun’s Scorching Surface

Publication Date: Friday
Source: The Tribune

NASA’s Parker Solar Probe has made a historic close approach to the sun, coming within a record-breaking 3.8 million miles (6 million kilometers) of its surface, successfully confirming its survival after the journey.

  • The probe was launched in 2018 to study the sun up close.
  • During its recent approach, it reached speeds of 430,000 mph (690,000 kph).
  • The spacecraft is equipped with a heat shield capable of withstanding temperatures up to 2,500 degrees Fahrenheit (1,370 degrees Celsius).
  • Scientists aim to use the data collected to understand the sun’s outer atmosphere and solar wind better.
“The data from Parker will help them better understand why the sun’s outer atmosphere is hundreds of times hotter than its surface.”

This remarkable achievement demonstrates the advances in space exploration technology, highlighting the Parker Solar Probe's contributions to solar science.
newTitle: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Survives Record-Breaking Close Approach to the Sun

title: NASA's Parker Solar Probe ‘safe’ after record-breaking brush with scorching surface, ‘phones home’ after several days | Mint - Mint
summary:
NASA’s Parker Solar Probe ‘safe’ after record-breaking brush with scorching surface, ‘phones home’ after several days

Publication Date: Recent Update | Source: NASA

The Parker Solar Probe has successfully survived its closest approach to the Sun, reaching within 6 million kilometers of the star’s surface. NASA confirmed that the spacecraft is safe and continues to operate normally after its historic flyby.

  • The Parker Solar Probe flew within 3.8 million miles (approximately 6 million kilometers) of the solar surface, marking the closest approach ever made by a human-made object.
  • The probe reported back to NASA on December 26, confirming its health and operational status after a brief period of silence during the flyby.
  • Launched in 2018, the Parker Solar Probe aims to study the Sun’s corona and the solar wind, contributing to our understanding of solar dynamics.
  • The spacecraft is equipped with a heat shield capable of withstanding temperatures up to 1370°C.
  • Scientists are hopeful that data collected during this mission will illuminate longstanding questions regarding the Sun's atmospheric temperatures and dynamics.
“Parker Solar Probe has phoned home! After passing just 3.8 million miles from the solar surface... we have received Parker Solar Probe’s beacon tone confirming the spacecraft is safe,” NASA stated.

The successful operations and data collection from the Parker Solar Probe contribute valuable insights into solar physics, aiming to unravel mysteries about the Sun that affect space weather and, by extension, life on Earth.
newTitle: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Successfully Completes Record-Breaking Approach to the Sun

title: 7 Mesmerising Images Of Star Clusters Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
7 Mesmerising Images Of Star Clusters Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Dec 27, 2024 | Source: Times Now

This article showcases stunning images of various star clusters captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting their unique features and significance in the universe.

  • NGC 3603: A vibrant star-forming region with a dense star cluster at its center.
  • R136: Home to some of the most massive stars discovered in the universe.
  • NGC 6397: One of the nearest globular clusters to Earth at approximately 7,800 light-years away.
  • 30 Doradus: The largest and most active star-forming region in our galaxy.
  • Artist’s Concept of the Arches Cluster: Known for its dense collection of young stars located near the Milky Way’s center.
  • NGC 346: Part of the most energetic star-forming region in the Small Magellanic Cloud.
  • N11: An area in the Large Magellanic Cloud known for its active star formation.
"These stunning images reveal the beauty and complexity of star formation in our universe." - Sparsh Sharma

In conclusion, the photographs serve to remind us of the vastness and splendor of the cosmos, encouraging further exploration and understanding of our universe.

title: India Will Miss Seeing Three Of The Four Eclipses In 2025, Says Ujjain Observatory - NDTV Profit
summary:
India Will Miss Seeing Three Of The Four Eclipses In 2025, Says Ujjain Observatory

Date: 27 Dec 2024, Source: PTI

The year 2025 will offer two solar and two lunar eclipses, but only one will be visible in India, according to Dr. Rajendra Prakash Gupt from the Jiwaji Observatory.

  • One total lunar eclipse on March 14 will not be visible in India as it occurs during the day.
  • A partial solar eclipse on March 29 will also be missed in India, visible only from North America and Europe.
  • A full lunar eclipse between September 7 and 8 will be visible in India and several other regions.
  • The final eclipse in 2025 will be a partial solar eclipse from September 21 to 22, which India will miss.
“This partial solar eclipse will be visible in New Zealand, Eastern Melanesia, Southern Polynesia and West Antarctica,” said Gupt.

India will have to wait for the one opportunity to witness a full lunar eclipse in 2025 amidst several missed opportunities.
newTitle: India Will Miss Seeing Three Of The Four Eclipses In 2025, Says Ujjain Observatory

title: Why NASA scientists are surprised by the discovery of 'tipped-over' black hole - DNA India
summary:
NASA's Surprising Discovery of a Tipped-Over Black Hole

Publication Date: N/A Source: DNA India

NASA scientists are puzzled by a new discovery regarding a supermassive black hole in the galaxy NGC 5084. This finding challenges existing assumptions about black holes.

  • This black hole exhibits unexpected behavior, as revealed by new imaging techniques on old data.
  • Four long plumes of hot plasma were discovered, arranged in a unique 'X' shape.
  • The black hole and its dusty disk are tilted 90 degrees relative to the galaxy's plane.
  • Such orientation suggests a possible past collision with another galaxy.
“This tilted position is not what scientists expected and adds a new layer to our understanding of black holes.”

This discovery not only reveals surprising traits of black holes but also prompts questions about their formation and evolution.
newTitle: NASA's Surprising Discovery of a Tipped-Over Black Hole

title: Study Reveals Chimpanzees Exhibit Varying Nut-Cracking Skills Within Same Group - Gadgets 360
summary:
Some Chimpanzees Crack Nuts Better than Others, New Study Shows

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Gadgets 360

A recent study has highlighted significant variations in nut-cracking abilities among chimpanzees in the same group, suggesting differences in cognitive and motor skills.

  • The research team analyzed 3,882 video instances of chimps attempting to crack nuts.
  • Five key factors measured included time taken, success rates, and the efficiency of different chimps.
  • Findings showed that proficiency in nut cracking generally improved with age.
  • No significant differences were found between male and female chimp nut-cracking skills.
“This research underscores the complexity of chimpanzee behaviour and provides a window into their problem-solving capabilities.”

This study enhances our understanding of primate tool use and cognitive variation, shedding light on behaviors that could parallel early human technological developments.
newTitle: Study Reveals Differences in Nut-Cracking Skills Among Chimpanzees

title: NASA spacecraft Parker Solar Probe ‘safe’ after closest-ever approach to the Sun - Hindustan Times
summary:
NASA Parker Solar Probe Safely Completes Historic Close Approach to the Sun

Publication Date: Dec 27, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

NASA's Parker Solar Probe has successfully completed its closest approach to the Sun, coming within 3.8 million miles (6.1 million km) of the solar surface and entering the corona. The spacecraft is reported to be in good health and operational.

  • The Parker Solar Probe transmitted a beacon signal confirming its status after the record-breaking approach.
  • The mission aims to enhance understanding of how solar material heats to millions of degrees and the origin of solar wind.
  • Traveling at speeds of up to 430,000 mph, the probe endured extreme temperatures of 1,800°F (982°C).
  • Mission Operations Manager Nick Pinkine noted the unprecedented nature of the probe's journey into uncharted territory.
“This close-up study of the Sun allows Parker Solar Probe to take measurements that help scientists better understand how material in this region gets heated to millions of degrees.” – NASA

This successful mission marks a significant step in solar exploration and understanding the dynamics of our nearest star.
newTitle: NASA Parker Solar Probe Safely Completes Historic Close Approach to the Sun

title: 2025 To Witness Four Eclipses Including Two Solar & Two Lunar, Only One Will Be Visible In India, Says Jiwaji - Free Press Journal
summary:
2025 To Witness Four Eclipses Including Two Solar & Two Lunar, Only One Will Be Visible In India, Says Jiwaji

Date & Source: Published on: December 27, 2024 - Source: Jiwaji Observatory

The year 2025 will have a total of four eclipses, comprising two solar and two lunar eclipses, but only one will be visible in India. The Jiwaji Observatory based in Ujjain provided details about the upcoming astronomical events.

  • March 14: Full lunar eclipse (not visible in India)
  • March 29: Partial solar eclipse (not visible in India)
  • September 7 and 8: Full lunar eclipse (visible in India)
  • September 21 and 22: Partial solar eclipse (not visible in India)
“Indian astronomy lovers can be excited by the fact that the full lunar eclipse occurring between September 7 and 8 will be visible in the country.” - Dr Rajendra Prakash Gupt

While 2024 had four celestial events, 2025 continues to generate interest among astronomy enthusiasts due to its limited visibility.
newTitle: 2025 To Witness Four Eclipses Including Two Solar & Two Lunar, Only One Will Be Visible In India, Says Jiwaji

title: The Growing Threat of Space Debris: Understanding the Kessler Syndrome - The Africa Logistics
summary:
The Growing Threat of Space Debris: Understanding the Kessler Syndrome

Date: [Insert Publication Date] | Source: theafricalogistics.com

The Kessler Syndrome highlights the dangers of space debris and its catastrophic implications for modern satellites and technology. With increasing satellite launches, the threat of collisions in low Earth orbit looms larger.

Key Points:

  • Satellite Mega-Constellations: The increase in satellites for global internet services raises collision risks.
  • Rocket Breakups: Recent disintegration of rockets adds to space debris concerns.
  • Close Calls in Space: Near-collisions are on the rise, endangering existing satellite infrastructure.
  • Rising Media Awareness: Global media emphasizes the urgency of addressing space debris.

Efforts to Mitigate the Threat:

  • Active Debris Removal: Developing technologies for capturing and removing space debris.
  • Smarter Satellite Design: Innovations like drag sails aim to reduce debris at the end of satellite lifecycles.
  • International Guidelines: UNOOSA promotes responsible space practices to minimize debris.
  • Collision Avoidance Systems: Advanced tracking systems are crucial for preventing impacts.

Conclusion:

The risks of Kessler Syndrome urge for global action to manage space debris effectively and sustainably.
newTitle: The Growing Threat of Space Debris: Understanding the Kessler Syndrome

summary:

The Parker Solar Probe has made history by becoming the first man-made object to complete a closest-ever approach to the Sun, and it's reported to be safe and operational.

  • The probe came within 3.8 million miles of the Sun's surface on December 24, 2023.
  • It transmitted a beacon tone indicating good health after the record-breaking approach.
  • The mission aims to uncover secrets about solar heat and solar wind.
  • The spacecraft is traveling at a speed of 430,000 mph and withstood temperatures up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit.
  • It has completed 21 passes of the Sun since its launch in 2018.

The detailed telemetry data on the probe's condition is expected on January 1, 2024.

title: Great magnetic drift: North Pole’s journey to Siberia - Telangana Today
summary:
Great Magnetic Drift: North Pole’s Journey to Siberia

Published Date: 27 December 2024, Source: Telangana Today

The magnetic North Pole is moving towards Russia at an unpredictable pace, causing concern among scientists due to its implications on global navigation systems.

  • The magnetic North Pole shifts due to convection currents in Earth’s outer core.
  • Recent movements have slowed from 55 km per year to 25 km per year.
  • This shift disrupts the World Magnetic Model (WMM) used in GPS and military navigation.
  • The movement may signal potential future magnetic pole reversals.
  • Robust monitoring is necessary to prepare for possible disruptions.
“This ongoing polar odyssey underscores the importance of vigilance in an ever-changing world.”

The shift of the magnetic North Pole toward Siberia raises alarm among scientists and highlights the importance of continued research and monitoring of Earth’s magnetic field.
newTitle: Great Magnetic Drift: North Pole’s Journey to Siberia

summary:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Approach to the Sun

Publication Date: December 24, 2023
Source: Economic Times

The Parker Solar Probe has successfully made its closest-ever approach to the Sun, coming within 3.86 million miles, setting a record for human-made objects.

  • The spacecraft is about the size of a small car and was launched in 2018.
  • This closest approach took place on December 24, 2023, within the solar corona.
  • The probe is designed to gather data about the Sun's outer atmosphere and solar wind.
  • Parker Solar Probe will endure extreme temperatures and speeds, moving at 430,000 mph.
  • It aims to solve mysteries regarding solar wind and the temperature of the corona.
“No human-made object has ever passed this close to a star, so Parker will truly be returning data from uncharted territory.” - Nick Pinkine, Mission Operations Manager

This monumental achievement marks a significant milestone in solar research, potentially leading to new insights into solar phenomena.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Approach to the Sun
